Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the mother needs to provide it
Situation2: They have been scheduled to chant a portion during the service.
Story: I stare at the calendar, my heart pounding. The rent is due next week, and the grocery list on the fridge grows longer every day. My boss just called—there’s an extra shift available at the store, but it’s on Saturday morning. I know we need the money; my children’s shoes are worn thin, and the fridge is nearly empty. But this Saturday isn’t just any Saturday. I’ve been asked to chant Torah at synagogue, something I haven’t done in years. The rabbi called me personally, saying how meaningful it would be for the community. My mother would be so proud. I can already picture my children watching me from the pews, their eyes wide. But if I don’t take the shift, how will I pay for what they need? I feel the weight of both worlds pressing down on me—my duty as a mother to provide, and my commitment as a Jew to honor Shabbat and my community. My hands tremble as I try to decide which expectation I can bear to disappoint.
